As an expatriate Canadian I lived and worked in Hong Kong for 13 fabulous years.

Early every morning I would go for a 60 minute walk and watch the city wake up. My favorite was to start on the Tsim Tsa Tsui waterfront to the Star Ferry terminal and watch my paper man put the sections together for the daily delivery. Then along a still quiet Nathan Road to Kowloon Park and the pink flamingos, exotic bird aviary, and elderly Chinese performing their daily ritual Tai Chi. Through the back lanes to the other end of the harbor walkway where the early morning harbor swimmers would sneak in beside the mail depot. The harbor from this side was always a spectacular view, even in the rain. Hong Kong has many great walks but this remained my favorite.

What makes you think that email providers would not turn over the encryption key to your mail on request? Even if the request was the result of a warrant, we know how empty the FISA court criteria for such warrants is,which in itself must inhibit free speech.

A useful application for all of us is one that would encrypt our email along with a 24x7 stream of encrypted rubbish, and post it to dropboxes (specific dropbox chosen by simple public hashcode of target email address) where potential recipients would scan the stream of posted messages to uncover the meaningful ones directed to them. The large encrypted stream from tens of millions of users would hopefully overwhelm the decryption capabilities of the NSA long enough for us to turn-out members of Congress who agree with the administration that total information collection is no problem.

It seems that the truth is that almost any and everything we say on the phone or write on our computers is accessible and can be used against us. A somewhat comical story was that a Christian missionary not too long ago in Turkey, there under other auspices to be able to do his main calling, had a problem with his computer. His hard drive failed and had to be replaced. So, he went to the local police station and asked for a copy of his hard drive so as to re-install it. They complied. He had only guessed that his hard drive was regularly backed up for spying purposes but found out that indeed, the State was into his computer totally.
From what I understand, Gmail is encrypted but most other email services are not. Apparently, the vast majority of major public universities have encryption for their email but relatively few small businesses which use common email providers leave their email unencrypted at all levels.
Likewise, phishing activity is apparently pretty easy for Internet providers to spot but most do not make the effort.
We have a great laxity which invites the equivalent of bedroom and backyard eavesdropping and even spying on business and proprietary activities. Perhaps, most do not care. From "sexting," most (consider Fmr Congressman Wiener) totally forget how vulnerable their activities are.
Well, at least insisting that all email providers encrypt and that all ISPs monitor and address suspicious activity would seem to be great first steps. Congress??

Many camps structure activities quite differently for each age group. The summer camp I attended when I was a child broke things up into age cohorts; my younger brother attended the same camp, but I only saw him at meal times, when we were at different tables. I have no idea what the specific camp described in the article does, but as a general principle, different developmental levels can be catered to at the same summer camp. In fact I would think virtually any good camp would offer this to some degree.

I'm interested that you send your children to two separate camps. I do sympathize with the idea of their being independent of one another, but are there really no camps that can accommodate both children's interests? Is it that they are attending specialized interest camps? Just curious.

Without meaning to be judgmental, I guess I find this situation a bit odd? I have daughters that are 10 and 8 years old. They share a room and they always have, but it would never occur to me to put them in the same camp. Even with only 22 months apart between them and both being of the same sex, they are on such different developmental levels I think it would be doing a disservice to both of them to put them together in a camp.

I feel like my older daughter already does enough as the older sibling, without having to carry over that responsibility into camp as well, which should be an experience that is free from sibling responsibility. On the other end of the spectrum, my younger child will never fully become self-sufficient if her older sibling is there to do things for her and look after her.

Add in an extra year and the children being opposite sexes and it really just makes no sense to me. Older siblings need to be able to find their own identity outside of being the caretaker of the younger ones and the younger ones need to learn to fend for themselves in a safe environment.

I am someone who encourages as much independence and self-reliance as possible with my children and even I think a two week sleep away is too much for a 7 year old.

Congress ignored his advance notice and so the Court had no choice but to strike it down.  His view of the commerce clause and the inability for Congress to require people to purchase a product in the ACA case was hardly radical:  the clause had never been read to give the legislature the ability to require that someone sitting in their home enter the stream of commerce by purchasing a product. On the other hand, bringing back elements of the CETA programs from the 70s and 80s, plus a renewed attention to apprenticeship programs might prove helpful.

I attended a CETA program in 1977, during a period where my next employment possibilities seemed hazy at best; I was going to emigrate.

But I heard of CETA, instead, and signed up. That program, in Hackensack, N.J. helped to focus my attentions firmly on what was then available in the employemnt world, and where I might fit in with my interests and talents, with the help of their workshops and excellent managers. Then I was encouraged to write a proposal, which I did, concerning a 6 month program, which I paid for partly with a CETA grant.

Upon completion of the program I was able to enter private industry, where I was gainfully employed for over 30 years.

At the time the media was full of scurrilous articles about "no show jobs" and "make work" and the like. I have no idea what they were on about; I worked in private industry and not for any dept. of government. Of course, all the scurrilous media attention sunk that useful program.

I figured that the Federal taxes I paid for that 30+ years were a return on investment (ROI) of the government's money, that otherwise I would've paid a foreign government, had I emigrated as I first intended.

So thank you CETA, and thank you President Carter.

I'm afraid you've gotten the passage about Frank Rich and David Gregory wrong, or at least left the most important part out. You write:

"Frank Rich, writing about the NBC-“Meet the Press” anchor David Gregory, smacked him around (as did many others) for asking Mr. Greenwald why he “shouldn’t be charged with a crime” for “the extent he aided and abetted” Mr. Snowden, the N.S.A. leaker."

"In a New York magazine piece, Mr. Rich wrote: “Is David Gregory a journalist?"

This would make far more sense if you included the important fact that David Gregory followed his question to Greenwald with this statement:

"The question of who's a journalist may be up to a debate with regards to what you're doing"

This wasn't a question, but a blunt statement of opinion by Gregory about Greenwald, and it was this that prompted Frank Rich's "Is David Gregory a journalist?".

The notion that someone like David Gregory, the TV host of what's at best a weekly Republican variety hour and and at worst a reality show, sneering at a columnist for an actual newspaper that he's not a "journalist" is one of the more astonishing examples of arrogance and lack of self awareness I've ever seen, and quite handily illustrates the way the Beltway is completely out of touch with reality.

By omitting that part you not only buried the lede, you buried it so deeply that it disappeared.
